Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Navigating Social Distancing with DeafBlind Children: Protactile Language Acquisition in an Online Learning Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Blanket directives to practice social distancing, while crucial to slowing the spread of COVID-19, do not take into account vulnerable populations such as DeafBlind children, who are at risk for social isolation and lack of critical language exposure. COVID-19 creates an immediate need for innovative and effective models of inclusive distance learning. This project will find ways to support language acquisition and cognitive development for the coming school year without increasing epidemiological risk. Conducting this research now stands to broaden our understanding of language, while also establishing models for education in populations that are disproportionately impacted by social distancing.<br/> <br/>Over the past decade, groups of DeafBlind adults in the United States began communicating directly with one another via reciprocal, tactile channels—a practice known as "protactile". These practices are leading to an emergent grammatical system that has yet to be acquired by any DeafBlind children. This project introduces a cohort of DeafBlind children to skilled protactile signers by combining video technology, a wearable haptic device designed for this project, and communication facilitators in the childrens’ homes. This hybrid approach will be evaluated as a remote learning environment to allow DeafBlind children to continue their learning at a distance consistent with slowing the spread of COVID-19. This approach will enable an analysis of the effects of the acquisition process as protactile language is transmitted from DeafBlind adult signers, who knew American Sign Language before protactile language, to DeafBlind children, who are acquiring protactile language as a first language. It is predicted that DeafBlind children will follow the general course of first language acquisition and will develop core lexical items earlier than verbs with componential morphology, thereby diverging from the path that adult signers have taken, creating forms with componential morphology before creating core lexical items. It is also predicted that the lexical forms created by children will adhere to protactile phonological principles more broadly than the forms created by adult protactile signers, whose application of protactile phonological principles is more restricted. If confirmed, the findings will show how DeafBlind children can acquire and expand language under conditions of social distancing, thereby modeling one way that education within vulnerable populations can be facilitated, while continuing to slow the spread of COVID-19<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Blanket directives to practice social distancing, while crucial to stopping the spread of COVID-19, do not consider vulnerable populations such as DeafBlind children, who under such conditions, are at risk for social isolation and lack of critical language exposure. The goal of this project was to find safe and effective ways of augmenting remote learning environments for supporting language acquisition and cognitive development in DeafBlind children by creating opportunities for them to learn ``Protactile'' a new, tactile language that has been emerging in communities of DeafBlind adults in the U.S. for the past 15 years. To this end, we combined in-person instruction provided by DeafBlind protactile researchers with online learning modules for parents and educators, augmented by an integrated wearable haptic device. This hybrid learning environment helped jump-start first language acquisition and offered a rare opportunity to study interactions between DeafBlind adults and children. In doing so, we gained important insight into how DeafBlind children acquire a first language under conditions of social distancing as well as their contribution to the emergence of a new language. 

With a team of DeafBlind, Deaf, and hearing researchers, we developed a program of research that involved protactile language early intervention. We collected data from 7 DeafBlind children, ages 8 months to 7 years, who did not have prior protactile language input. In documenting their interactions with DeafBlind protactile adults, we focused on how DeafBlind adults provided protactile input to DeafBlind children. In preliminary analyses, we found that protactile ``taps'', which have taken on increasingly grammatical functions among DeafBlind adults, played an important role for the children. In response to frequent tapping on the part of the DeafBlind adults, and in combination with consistent exposure to the conventional organization of the articulators in protactile language, the children responded by attending more closely and more consistently to the parts of the adults? bodies where information is conventionally concentrated (e.g. the hands, the arms, the chest, and the leg), as well as producing information with their own, corresponding articulators, rather than the non-conventionalized articulators (e.g. the mouth and head), thereby establishing communication channels. This shift toward a conventional set of articulators and channels generated important scaffolding for exposure to, and recognition of, phonological patterns in protactile language.

As part of this project, we created novel and innovative technological and methodological tools. First, in order to augment in-person instruction and make remote communication more tactile, we created a website (deafblindkids.org). The site includes a set of learning modules for parents and educators, which is integrated with a wearable haptic device that will allow parents and educators to practice basic protactile skills remotely. Second, because protactile language is new and no research has been undertaken to understand how it is acquired by children, there are no tools for measuring or tracking progress. Therefore, we created the Tactile Communication and Protactile Language (TCPL) checklist? the first of its kind? for DeafBlind children and early protactile development. The TCPL will be important in measuring and analyzing the acquisition of protactile language and related communication behaviors in this project and beyond. 

Intellectual merits: This research lays the foundation for future work on how child learners contribute to language emergence and change, and offers insights, for the first time, into how language at the phonological level is optimized to the tactile modality by children who acquire it. Broader impacts: DeafBlind children are disproportionately affected by social distancing. We have developed tools and resources to offset those effects during this critical time of language development. This work also raises awareness of DeafBlind child language acquisition and socialization in the educational setting, in the family setting, and in society at large.
